item.title: [HBASE-8461] Provide the ability to delete multiple snapshots through single command
item.description:
Currently HBaseAdmin#deleteSnapshot() accepts name of single snapshot.

It is desirable to allow user to delete multiple snapshots by issuing one command.
e.g. user may use regular expression to specify the names of snapshots to delete.
item.summary: Provide the ability to delete multiple snapshots through single command

deleteSnapshot(regex) {

      getMaster().deleteSnapshot(snapshot);

   }

}

+1 on patch (client only API change is fine).

Hey guys, just saw this. I'm concerned about this for delete and actually thinking about that also concerned about the list method.

ex:

 

// API call 

deleteSnapshots(".*")

This will delete all snapshots. (not just those starting with '.'). If people thing of these as file regexes instead of java regexes they might delete things, especially if there is no ability to do a confirmation.

I also don't think we should widen the hbase admin api for this. Why not just have this in the jruby shell like this[1]? We do similar things for listing and removing tables there and with deleting tables we have the enable/disable safeguard.

[1] https://github.com/apache/hbase/blob/trunk/hbase-server/src/main/ruby/shell/commands/list.rb

There was existing API deleteTables() which accepts regex:


  public HTableDescriptor[] deleteTables(String regex) throws IOException {

    return deleteTables(Pattern.compile(regex));

  }

I don't see user given a chance for confirmation w.r.t. the above API.

list.rb calls admin.list(regex) which accepts regex.
In the delete tables case, you must explicitly disable the table before you can delete it. With snapshots there is no similar safeguard. If it is in jruby we can do so interactively.

Good point – though I'd actually prefer it if list was handled in the jruby as well. I'm really mostly concerned about widening the public api of things like the client or the admin – ideally they should be as thin as necessary (and no thinner).
